conclusion: Problem involves two parallel metal rails inclined at 30 degrees in a uniform magnetic field pointing vertically upwards.
Two conductor rods, a and b, have different masses and same resistance; rod a is pulled with constant force F.
Objective is to find speed of rod b when joule heat in rod a is 0.12 J and its velocity is 1.0 m/s.
Forces acting on rods include gravity and magnetic force due to magnetic field and induced current.
Faraday's law and Lenz's law are relevant due to electromagnetic induction as rods move.
Two rods, a and b, move on parallel rails; rod a is pulled up with force F, rod b moves down due to gravity.
Magnetic field is vertical, magnetic force is perpendicular to both velocity and magnetic field.
Magnetic field is directed vertically upward relative to the plane of the rails.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the rails inclined at 30 degrees.
Velocity of rods is along rails inclined at 30 degrees; magnetic field is perpendicular to rails.
Magnetic force on each rod is F_magnetic = I * L * B.
Induced emf in each rod due to motion in magnetic field.
Relative motion between rods induces emf in circuit formed by rods and rails.
Emf induced in circuit is emf = (v_a - v_b) * B * L.
Assuming magnetic field is uniform and perpendicular to motion.
Current in circuit is I = emf / (2R) = (v_a - v_b) * B * L / (2R).
Circuit consists of two rods and rails; total resistance is R_a + R_b = 2R.
Magnetic force on each rod is F_magnetic = I * L * B.
Direction of magnetic force depends on direction of current and magnetic field.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to rails; current flows through rods.
Magnetic force on rod a is opposite to its motion due to induced current.
